items.title: Travelers brace for chaos as US government shutdown threatens holiday flights
items.standfirst: Travellers braced for cancelled flights, disrupted plans and holidays spent stranded in airports as a US government shutdown loomed, threatening to throw journeys nationwide into disarray. News that the Federal Aviation Administration will scale back air traffic operations at 40 airports starting Friday sparked a wave of concern among those preparing to travel. France24 correspondent Fraser Jackson tells us the latest.
items.content: Travellers braced for cancelled flights, disrupted plans and holidays spent stranded in airports as a US government shutdown loomed, threatening to throw journeys nationwide into disarray. News that the Federal Aviation Administration will scale back air traffic operations at 40 airports starting Friday sparked a wave of concern among those preparing to travel. France24 correspondent Fraser Jackson tells us the latest.

items.title: Shutdown in the US: Over 2,000 flights affected at major airports
items.standfirst: Airlines canceled more than 1,000 flights Friday and hundreds more for Saturday at major airports across the United States as they scrambled to comply with a Trump administration order to reduce air traffic amid growing concerns about the impact potential staffing shortages could have on aviation safety. Camille Knight reports.
items.content: Airlines canceled more than 1,000 flights Friday and hundreds more for Saturday at major airports across the United States as they scrambled to comply with a Trump administration order to reduce air traffic amid growing concerns about the impact potential staffing shortages could have on aviation safety. Camille Knight reports.

items.title: FAA order cutting thousands of flights kicks in as airlines scramble to comply
items.standfirst: The FAA ordered airlines to cut thousands of flights beginning Friday as the agency deals with air traffic controller shortages during the government shutdown.
items.content: The FAA ordered airlines to cut thousands of flights beginning Friday as the agency deals with air traffic controller shortages during the government shutdown.

items.title: US travellers scramble to adjust as hundreds of flights are cancelled over shutdown
items.standfirst: Hundreds of flight cancellations spread across the US on Friday as airlines began complying with the Federal Aviation Administration's unprecedented order to reduce service nationwide because of the government shutdown. FRANCE 24's Fraser Jackson brings us the latest from Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington, DC, and speaks to travellers stranded amid the travel chaos.
items.content: Hundreds of flight cancellations spread across the US on Friday as airlines began complying with the Federal Aviation Administration's unprecedented order to reduce service nationwide because of the government shutdown. FRANCE 24's Fraser Jackson brings us the latest from Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington, DC, and speaks to travellers stranded amid the travel chaos.

items.title: Traveling soon? What the FAA's flight reductions could mean for you
items.standfirst: The FAA is cutting 10% of air traffic at 40 of the nation's busiest airports, canceling hundreds of flights and creating uncertainty for many more passengers. Here's what to do if you're one of them.
items.content: The FAA is cutting 10% of air traffic at 40 of the nation's busiest airports, canceling hundreds of flights and creating uncertainty for many more passengers. Here's what to do if you're one of them.(Image credit: Timothy A. Clary)

items.title: The FAA's air traffic reductions are taking effect. Here's what to know
items.standfirst: Airlines are canceling hundreds of flights to comply with the FAA's order. But there are still questions about the plan, which the agency says will keep the skies safe during the government shutdown.
items.content: Airlines are canceling hundreds of flights to comply with the FAA's order. But there are still questions about the plan, which the agency says will keep the skies safe during the government shutdown.(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

Travelers face mounting delays and disruptions as the government shutdown continues.
Air traffic controller shortages are causing flight cancellations and delays nationwide.
The government shutdown has no end in sight, exacerbating travel issues.

France24 correspondent Noga Tarnopolsky reports the latest.

items.title: Turkey issues genocide arrest warrant against Benjamin Netanyahu
items.standfirst: Israeli PM, ministers and army chief accused of crimes against humanity ‘perpetrated systematically’ in GazaTurkey has issued arrest warrants for alleged genocide against the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and senior officials within his government.Among 37 suspects listed were the Israeli defence minister, Israel Katz, the national security minister, Itamar Ben-Gvir, and the army chief Lt Gen Eyal Zamir, said a statement from the Istanbul prosecutor’s office, which did not publish the complete list. Continue reading...
items.content: Israeli PM, ministers and army chief accused of crimes against humanity ‘perpetrated systematically’ in GazaTurkey has issued arrest warrants for alleged genocide against the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and senior officials within his government.Among 37 suspects listed were the Israeli defence minister, Israel Katz, the national security minister, Itamar Ben-Gvir, and the army chief Lt Gen Eyal Zamir, said a statement from the Istanbul prosecutor’s office, which did not publish the complete list. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Turkey issued arrest warrants for Benjamin Netanyahu and 36 other Israeli officials.
The warrants accuse the officials of genocide and crimes against humanity in Gaza.
The Istanbul prosecutor's office issued the warrants, according to The Guardian.
The warrants target senior Israeli officials, including ministers and military leaders.
Israel has received the remains of another hostage from Gaza.

items.title: Trump exempts Hungary from US sanctions on Russian energy after meeting Orban

items.content: Hungary has been given a one-year exemption from US sanctions on using Russian energy, a White House official has said, after its Prime Minister Viktor Orban met with Donald Trump in the White House.

Trump slapped sanctions on Moscow’s two largest oil companies in October after…

items.title: Trump agrees a one-year exemption on Russian energy sanctions for Hungary
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump gave Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban a one-year reprieve from sanctions for buying Russian oil and gas on Friday after the leaders heaped praise on each other during a meeting at the While House. Trump has pushed other EU countries to stop buying Russian oil but he said landlocked Hungary was exempt as it is reliant on pipelines that lead to Russia.
items.content: US President Donald Trump gave Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban a one-year reprieve from sanctions for buying Russian oil and gas on Friday after the leaders heaped praise on each other during a meeting at the While House. Trump has pushed other EU countries to stop buying Russian oil but he said landlocked Hungary was exempt as it is reliant on pipelines that lead to Russia.

items.title: Trump gives Hungary one-year exemption from Russian energy sanctions
items.standfirst: The opt-out comes despite the US increasing pressure on allies to sever economic ties with Russia.
items.content: The opt-out comes despite the US increasing pressure on allies to sever economic ties with Russia.

items.title: Trump-Orbán meeting: US gives Hungary exemption from sanctions on Russian oil and gas
items.standfirst: US president also praises Hungarian leader’s hardline stance on immigration during friendly White House summitThe US has granted Hungary a one-year exemption from US sanctions on importing oil and gas from Russia, according to a White House official, after Viktor Orbán pressed his case for a reprieve during a meeting with Donald Trump in Washington.Last month, Trump imposed Ukraine-related sanctions on Russian oil companies Lukoil and Rosneft that carried the threat of further sanctions on entities in countries buying oil from them. Continue reading...
items.content: US president also praises Hungarian leader’s hardline stance on immigration during friendly White House summitThe US has granted Hungary a one-year exemption from US sanctions on importing oil and gas from Russia, according to a White House official, after Viktor Orbán pressed his case for a reprieve during a meeting with Donald Trump in Washington.Last month, Trump imposed Ukraine-related sanctions on Russian oil companies Lukoil and Rosneft that carried the threat of further sanctions on entities in countries buying oil from them. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Donald Trump granted Hungary a one-year exemption from sanctions on Russian oil and gas.
The exemption was given after a meeting between Trump and Hungarian Prime Minister Orban.
Trump has pushed other EU countries to stop buying Russian oil.
Hungary is reliant on pipelines that lead to Russia.
The US is increasing pressure on allies to sever economic ties with Russia.

items.title: What to know about the 5 hostages whose remains are still in Gaza
items.standfirst: In the most recent release, Hamas returned the remains of an Israeli man who died while fighting Hamas in the Oct. 7, 2023 attack. He was identified as Lior Rudaeff, who was 61 when he was killed.
items.content: In the most recent release, Hamas returned the remains of an Israeli man who died while fighting Hamas in the Oct. 7, 2023 attack. He was identified as Lior Rudaeff, who was 61 when he was killed.(Image credit: Jehad Alshrafi)

items.title: Israel identifies returned remains as Israel-Argentine hostage killed at start of war
items.standfirst: Israel on Saturday said it had identified the latest remains returned by Hamas as Israeli Argentinian Lior Rudaeff, who was killed by the militant group in its cross-border attack on October 7, 2023. Rudaeff's body was transported by Hamas to Gaza where it remained until Friday.
items.content: Israel on Saturday said it had identified the latest remains returned by Hamas as Israeli Argentinian Lior Rudaeff, who was killed by the militant group in its cross-border attack on October 7, 2023. Rudaeff's body was transported by Hamas to Gaza where it remained until Friday.

clusters.title: At least 54 people injured in explosions at Indonesian school mosque
clusters.neutral_headline: Multiple explosions shake a mosque in an Indonesian high school, injuring dozens

items.title: At least 54 people injured in explosions at Indonesian school mosque
items.standfirst: Authorities say suspect is 17-year-old male student and warn against terrorist attack speculation after Jakarta blasts At least 54 people have been injured in explosions that shook a mosque at a high school during Friday prayers in the Indonesian capital, Jakarta. Authorities later said the suspect was a 17-year-old male student who had been injured and was undergoing surgery.Witnesses told local television stations that they heard at least two loud blasts at about midday, just as the sermon had started, from inside and outside the mosque at SMA 72, a state high school within a navy compound in Jakarta’s northern Kelapa Gading neighbourhood. Continue reading...
items.content: Authorities say suspect is 17-year-old male student and warn against terrorist attack speculation after Jakarta blasts At least 54 people have been injured in explosions that shook a mosque at a high school during Friday prayers in the Indonesian capital, Jakarta. Authorities later said the suspect was a 17-year-old male student who had been injured and was undergoing surgery.Witnesses told local television stations that they heard at least two loud blasts at about midday, just as the sermon had started, from inside and outside the mosque at SMA 72, a state high school within a navy compound in Jakarta’s northern Kelapa Gading neighbourhood. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: Consumer sentiment tumbles close to record lows in latest U Michigan survey NEW YORK (AP) — Consumer sentiment dropped to a three-year low and close to the lowest point ever recorded by the University of Michigan one month into the government shutdown, with pessimism over personal finances and…
items.content: Consumer sentiment tumbles close to record lows in latest U Michigan survey NEW YORK (AP) — Consumer sentiment dropped to a three-year low and close to the lowest point ever recorded by the University of Michigan one month into the government shutdown, with pessimism over personal finances and…

items.title: US consumer sentiment drops to near record low as shutdown persists
items.standfirst: Economic concerns felt by Americans of different ages, incomes and political affiliations, survey findsThe federal government shutdown dragged consumer sentiment in the US to a near record low in November, according to a monthly survey conducted by the University of Michigan.Consumer sentiment fell about 6% in November, with the consumer sentiment index for November 2025 at 50.3, down from 53.6 in October, nearly three points below expectations. Economists polled by the Wall Street Journal expected a 53.0 index reading. Continue reading...
items.content: Economic concerns felt by Americans of different ages, incomes and political affiliations, survey findsThe federal government shutdown dragged consumer sentiment in the US to a near record low in November, according to a monthly survey conducted by the University of Michigan.Consumer sentiment fell about 6% in November, with the consumer sentiment index for November 2025 at 50.3, down from 53.6 in October, nearly three points below expectations. Economists polled by the Wall Street Journal expected a 53.0 index reading. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Consumer sentiment dropped to a three-year low.
The drop is close to the lowest point ever recorded.
The survey was conducted by the University of Michigan.
The government shutdown is one month old.

clusters.title: Trump says US will not attend South Africa's G20 due to white farmer 'abuse'

items.title: Trump says US will not attend South Africa's G20 due to white farmer 'abuse'
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump said none of his country's officials would attend the G20 summit in Johannesburg in November, in protest against "human rights abuses" in South Africa. Since Trump returned to the White House in January he has frequently made false claims of a "white genocide" against Afrikaners.
items.content: US President Donald Trump said none of his country's officials would attend the G20 summit in Johannesburg in November, in protest against "human rights abuses" in South Africa. Since Trump returned to the White House in January he has frequently made false claims of a "white genocide" against Afrikaners.

items.title: Trump says US will boycott G20 summit in South Africa, citing treatment of white farmers
items.standfirst: Administration has long accused South Africa of allowing white Afrikaner farmers to be persecuted and attackedDonald Trump said Friday that no US government officials would be attending the Group of 20 summit this year in South Africa, citing the country’s treatment of white farmers.The US president had already announced he would not attend the annual summit for heads of state from the globe’s leading and emerging economies. JD Vance had been scheduled to attend in Trump’s place, but a person familiar with Vance’s plans who was granted anonymity to talk about his schedule said Vance would no longer travel there for the summit. Continue reading...
items.content: Administration has long accused South Africa of allowing white Afrikaner farmers to be persecuted and attackedDonald Trump said Friday that no US government officials would be attending the Group of 20 summit this year in South Africa, citing the country’s treatment of white farmers.The US president had already announced he would not attend the annual summit for heads of state from the globe’s leading and emerging economies. JD Vance had been scheduled to attend in Trump’s place, but a person familiar with Vance’s plans who was granted anonymity to talk about his schedule said Vance would no longer travel there for the summit. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Trump stated the US would not attend the G20 summit in South Africa.
He cited concerns about human rights abuses, specifically treatment of white farmers.
Trump has previously made false claims of "white genocide" against Afrikaners.
JD Vance was scheduled to attend but will no longer travel to the summit.
The US president announced he would not attend the annual summit.

items.standfirst: International mediators broker three-month halt to civil war as further evidence emerges of mass civilian killingsA Sudanese paramilitary group accused of killing thousands of unarmed civilians in an ethnically motivated massacre has agreed to a truce.The Rapid Support Forces (RSF), which is facing mounting criticism over apparent war crimes committed by its fighters in the city of El Fasher last month, said it had agreed to a “humanitarian ceasefire” put forward by the quad countries of the US, Egypt, the UAE and Saudi Arabia.
